metadata.title: Recent Advances in the Design of Tailored Nanomaterials for Efficient Oxygen Reduction Reaction

sections.text:
In the past decade, polymer electrolyte membrane fuels (PEMFCs) have been evaluated for both automotive and stationary applications. One of the main obstacles for large scale commercialization of this technology is related to the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction that takes place on the cathode side of fuel cell. Consequently, ongoing research efforts are focused on the design of cathode materials that could improve the kinetics and durability. Majority of these efforts rely on novel synthetic approaches that provide control over the structure, size, shape and composition of catalytically active materials. This article highlights the most recent advances that have been made to tailor critical parameters of the nanoscale materials in order to achieve more efficient performance of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR).
Keywords: Pt alloys, fuel cells, nanoparticles, electrocatalysis, oxygen reduction reaction

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Fuel cells technology is viewed as the most promising alternative to the internal combustion engines in automotive applications that could substantially decrease reliance on fossil fuels [1–3]. In a typical polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC), the main fuel is hydrogen, which through its reaction with oxygen produces electricity with water as the only product [4,5]. Platinum nanoparticles (NPs) dispersed in high surface area carbon have been regarded as the most efficient materials in catalyzing both the hydrogen fuel oxidation (HOR) and the oxygen reduction reaction
(ORR) with favorable voltage output and relatively low electrochemical over potentials. Unfortunately, limited resources and high cost of Pt are viewed as significant obstacles to wide spread commercialization of fuel cells. Moreover, Pt NPs at the cathode under electrochemical oxidation conditions tend to migrate and grow through Oswald ripening process, more details are given by Cherevko and Mayrhofer in this Electrocatalysis Special Issue [6]. Consequently, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) and the catalytic efficiency are compromised, which lead to unfavorable increase in over potentials for fuel-cell reactions, especially for the ORR [7–9] . Therefore, a number of research efforts have been aimed towards the design of Pt-based nanoscale materials with controlled shape, composition and size in order to minimize the cost by decreasing the amount of Pt while enhancing both the activity and durability. When the size of particles is reduced to the nanoscale dimensions, different physical and chemical properties that are not observed in the bulk state can emerge, which extend opportunities to develop low-cost Pt-based materials and provide ability to address critical issues in real-world applications [10–12]. Here, it should be emphasized that the majority of electrochemical processes are dependent on the surface structure, and hence, it has been well established that the kinetic of the ORR on Pt surfaces varies with the crystal face. For that reason, importance to have control over the critical parameters of NPs has led to development of chemical and physical methods that can deliver tailored nanoscale materials with optimal catalytic performance [13– 15]. The recent advances in the organic solution phase synthesis of metal nanoparticles are given by Li and Sun in this Electrocatalysis Special Issue [16]. The main goal of this review is to highlight recent advances in synthesis of the most promising Pt-based catalysts for the ORR, and also to provide an overview on alternative systems such as Pt-free catalysts and non-precious metal materials that can efficiently reduce molecular oxygen.

sections.heading: 2 Mechanism of the ORR
sections.text:
When compared to the anodic hydrogen oxidation reaction, the ORR requires
significant overpotential [17,18]. At the same time, this is a multielectron reaction that may include several elementary steps involving different reaction intermediates. Recent studies have demonstrated that a series pathway via an (H2O2)ads intermediate may be operative on Pt and Pt-bimetallic catalysts and the rate determining step (RDS) is considered to be the first electron transfer from the topmost electrode surface to the adsorbed molecular oxygen O2ads. Peroxide that is formed depending on applied conditions, and type of catalyst may or may not be reduced to water. Therefore, the exact atomic-level understanding of the ORR on metal surfaces still remains challenging due to complexity of the ORR kinetics. The distinction between the ORR mechanisms is based on the number of proton-coupled electron transfer steps that precede the O-O bond breaking step. While under acidic conditions Pt-based systems are the mainstream for the ORR catalyst materials, in alkaline electrolyte a wide range of non-noble metals and their oxides are found to be stable enough for practical applications. Fundamentally, the mechanism of the ORR in acidic media involves either the direct four-electron reduction pathway from O2 to produce H2O: O2+4H + +4e - →2H2O; or the two-electron reduction pathway from O2 to H2O2, followed by another 2e - reduction to convert H2O2 into H2O: O2+2H + +2e - →H2O2; H2O2+2H + +e - →2H2O [19–23]. Water is directly produced when oxygen is reduced through the four-electron reduction mechanism. On the other hand, the two-electron reduction occurs at low potentials produces hydrogen peroxide as an intermediate and byproduct. It has been accepted that at high potentials (low overpotential absolute value) and high coverage by adsorbed oxygenated intermediate species, the Tafel slope is 60 mV per decade and the reaction order is 3/2 in respect to H + activity. The adsorbed intermediate species are considered to be Oads, OHads and OOHads, in which OOHads is formed first, and then the O-O bond is being broken. In contrast, at low potentials (high overpotential absolute value) and the low coverage, the Tafel slope is 120 mV per decade and the reaction order is 1, while the ORR follows a dissociation mechanism in which the O-O bond is broken before OHads is formed [22–24]. Combined experimental and theoretical studies have provided important clues for the structure function relationship and enhanced performance of the ORR, and moreover, have established
composition function correlation for Pt alloy surfaces [25]. For instance, a volcano-type correlation between the specific activity for the ORR and the d-band center position vs. metallic Fermi level was established for a series of Pt-alloy systems as shown in Figure 1. The overall consequence of this trend can be summarized in the following statement: in order to facilitate the maximum catalytic activity for the ORR, the adsorption energies of reactive intermediates and surface coverage by spectator oxygenated species as well as specifically adsorbed anions on the catalyst surface should be balanced. If the catalyst binds oxygen too strongly, as in the case of Pt, the ORR activity is restricted by the rate of removing surface oxides and anions from surface. On the other hand, when the catalysts bind oxygen too weakly, as in the case of Pt3V and Pt3Ti, the ORR activity is slowed down by the rate of transferring electron and proton to adsorbed O2. Therefore, the better ORR catalysts should bind oxygen more weakly than that of Pt, and more strongly than that of Pt3V and Pt3Ti. In this case, Ni, Co, and Fe are found to be the most effective alloying elements. The knowledge established by studying electrocatalytic trends on extended surfaces provided fundamental guidance for the development of existing cathode nanocatalysts.

sections.heading: 3 ORR on Pt Surfaces
sections.text:
The specific activity of the catalyst towards the ORR changes with crystallite size due to well established structure sensitivity of this reaction. Moreover, the oxygen reduction kinetics is also directly affected by the presence of so-called specifically adsorbed anions as well by the differences in adsorption energy in nonadsorbing electrolytes. An observable crystallite size effect is the only evidence for nanoscale materials that the reaction may be structure sensitive [26,27]. For that reason, bulk single crystals have thoroughly been used to investigate the mechanistic reaction pathways of the ORR, providing valuable insight into the link between well-defined surface properties and nanoscale catalysts [28,29]. It has been demonstrated that the ORR activity on single-crystalline surfaces of Pt increases in the order Pt(100)<Pt(111)<Pt(110) in weakly adsorbing electrolytes of perchloric acid (HClO4), while in the strongly adsorbing electrolytes of sulfuric acid (H2SO4), the ORR activity
increases in the order Pt(111)<Pt(110)<Pt(100) due to the stronger adsorption of sulfate anion (SO4 2- ) on Pt(111) versus on Pt(100) which limits accessibility of Pt sites, and hence, the O2 adsorption [30,31]. Therefore, the strength of the anion adsorption and its correlation to surface structure always needs to be considered in order to understand the structure-function properties of certain reaction. In addition to characterization of low index surfaces, Feliu and coworkers reported the ORR kinetics on the stepped Pt surfaces in acidic media. They employed Pt single crystals belonging to the [011̅] and [11̅0] zones to understand the effect of surface structure on the ORR [32,33]. On the other hand, utilization of the thin-film approach is an intriguing alternative to costly single crystalline samples. It has been shown that the thin-film surface ordering upon controlled heat-treatment is driven by a tendency of the system to expose the (111) facets due to the lowest surface energy. However, promotion of the (111) orientation for thin films derived by physical vapor deposition (PVD) methods is often very challenging and exhibits rough surface morphology with holes and large clusters, which often lack the long-range order required to exhibit characteristic cyclic voltammetry (CV). Recently, a rapid and reproducible approach for generating thin metal films that exhibit strong (111) character without the use of epitaxial templates was presented by our group, and it is shown in Figure 2 [34]. Thermal annealing in a controlled atmosphere induces long-range ordering in magnetron sputtered thin metal films deposited on glassy carbon (GC) electrodes. The CV curves of the annealed Pt thin film show characteristic fingerprint adsorption features characteristic of Pt(111) single crystals in both HClO4 and H2SO4 electrolytes, Figure 2D and E. The magnitude of the butterfly peak currents for the annealed Pt thin film are nearly equal to those of Pt(111), indicative of the long-range ordering, which is also further confirmed by a butterfly peak at ~0.5 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M H2SO4 electrolyte (Figure 2E). The ordering transition yields characteristic (111) electrochemical signatures with minimal amount of material and provides an adequate replacement for oriented bulk single crystals. Extension of this process to other metal and alloy thin films can facilitate development of a new class of thin-film-based catalysts. Pt has a face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure with a lattice parameter of 3.93 Å.
The surface energies of the low-index crystallographic planes are in the order of Pt(111)<Pt (100) <Pt(110). Because of the high density of atomic steps, ledges, and kinks, high-index planes of Pt usually shows enhanced catalytic activity as compared to the most common low-index planes. More recently, Sun and coworkers have reported the synthesis of tetrahexahedral (THH) Pt nanocrystals with high-index facets, such as (730), (210), and (520), by applying a square-wave potential to polycrystalline Pt microspheres supported on a GC electrode [35]. Besides THH Pt nanocrystals, concave nanocrystals were also made and shown to have a different set of high index facets, which was demonstrated in the study of 15-40 nm concave Pt NPs. Another study performed by Xia and coworkers. the synthesis of concave cubic Pt nanoparticles enclosed by high-index facets including (510), (720) and (830) facets by a simple route based on reduction in an aqueous solution (See Figure 3) was reported [36]. In the formation of Pt concave nanocubes, the slow reduction of Pt pyrophosphato complex and addition of this precursor by controlling the reaction rate with a syringe pump was the key to the success in this approach. The surface of the Pt concave nanocube was mainly enclosed by (720) facets, together with some other high-index facets. As shown in Figure 3B, the Pt concave cubes exhibited higher specific activity than the Pt cubes and cubooctahedrons due to higher index surfaces. However, the mass activity of Pt concave cubes was still less than that of the Pt/C catalyst owing to their smaller ECSA associated with the relatively larger particle size. This work presented another approach of kinetic control for synthesizing nanocrystals with high-index surfaces, and it is expected to be extended to other nanoscale systems. In contrast to surface structure sensitivity, the Pt particle size effect on the ORR is still controversial in the field. In our recent work, functional links between Pt single crystal morphology and nanoparticles with different size and shape were successfully established for the ORR [37]. We have found that the ORR activity of well dispersed and uniform Pt NPs is indeed, dependant on their size, and the effect will be decreased in the range of 2 to 7 nm; meanwhile, the particle shape effect when compared between octahedral and cubic particles is less pronounced especially after moderate potential cycling. High resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) and scanning
transmission electron microscope (STEM) images for octahedral and cubic NPs are shown in Figure 4. It is important to mention that despite their distinctive morphology, the CVs confirm defects dominated surfaces (Figure 4C and F). Moreover, both shapes ended up being round after durability test (Figure 4B and E) although mean diameter remained the same. Regardless of an initial shape, NPs were found to be metastable and evolve to thermodynamically equilibrated shape with similar activity for the ORR. Meanwhile, the monodisperse 7 nm cubo-octahedral Pt NPs represent a reasonable balance or compromise between the mass activity and durability. Consequently, for the given examples and experimental conditions, the particle size and shape effects diminish as the particles age to the point that it may appear that the ORR depends neither on the particle size nor particle shape.

sections.heading: 4 Pt Bimetallic and Multimetallic Catalysts for ORR
4.1 Alloys
sections.text:
Alloys have attracted increasing interest in the pursuit to develop advanced electrocatalysts, which would not only decrease the content of expensive Pt metal, but would also enhance the catalytic activity and durability. The Pt alloys possess d-band vacancies per atom (electronic) and contractions in the Pt-Pt bond distances (geometric) relative to pure Pt. Mukerjee et al. were among the first to report on the interplay between the electronic and geometric factors and their effect on the chemisorption of OH species from the electrolyte that could enhance the catalytic activity of Pt-alloys [38]. As discussed in the previous section, specific activities of the MPt alloys show a volcano-type relationship in respect to the metallic d-band center position. As of now, alloying Pt in the form of NPs with 3d transition metals (M=Fe, Co, and Ni) have shown much more potential in tailoring the atomic and electronic structures of catalytically active materials toward improved ORR activities than any other approach. Recently, we reported that extended single crystal surface of Pt3Ni(111) that shows 10 times higher specific activity than the corresponding Pt(111) surface and 90 times than the current state-of-the-art Pt/C catalysts for the ORR in 0.1 M HClO4 solution, as
shown in Figure 5 [39]. The Pt3Ni(111) crystal has the fcc lattice with random occupation of sites by Pt and Ni, which gives rise to surface x-ray scattering (SXS) similar to that obtained from a monocrystalline fcc lattice. The three outermost surface layers of Pt3Ni(111) crystal were found to be crucial in determining unique properties of this system: the third layer was Pt-enriched, with a Pt content of 87%; the middle atomic layer was Ni-enriched, with 52% Ni; and the outer layer contained almost 100% Pt. As summarized, the different low-index surfaces of Pt3Ni showed markedly different ORR activity, increased in the order Pt3Ni(100)-skin < Pt3Ni(110)-skin < Pt3Ni(111)-skin with the change in activity between the least active (100) and the most active (111) surfaces being greater than an order of magnitude. The differences in the ORR activity had been attributed to the structure-sensitive adsorption of OHads on Pt(hkl) and its inhibiting (site blocking) effect on O2 adsorption, the Pt3Ni(111) surface exhibited low OHads coverage during the ORR, induced by altered electronic surface properties after alloying. This report has largely determined a research focus that aimed to synthesize nanoscale Pt-alloy system with Pt(111)-skin as outermost surface layer. However, in order to execute systematic approach in synthesis of tailored nanoparticles, it was necessary to establish functional properties of well-defined nanoscale systems. As discussed above, the ORR activity is size dependent on the pure Pt NPs. Meanwhile, the distribution of elements within the NPs is found to have remarkable effects on the local electronic structures and catalytic behavior of the alloy NPs. As a result of the alloying effect, the Pt-alloy NPs with 3d transition metals exhibited a trend for their size and composition dependent catalytic activity [40–42]. A series of homogeneous Pt3M (where M = Fe, Ni, or Co) nanocatalysts with controllable particle size and composition obtained by an organic solvothermal method were tested for their ORR performance [43,44]. The synthesis was executed by coupling the reduction of platinum acetylacetonate with the reduction of 3d transition metal salts or thermal decomposition of metal carbonyl [44]. Figure 6A-C shows a typical TEM image of the monodisperse ~5 nm Pt3M NPs, while the particle size was controlled from <3 nm to ~10 nm, and the alloy composition was varied from Pt-rich to 3d transition metal-rich [45,46]. At 0.9 V, the Pt3M catalysts showed improvement factors of ~2-3 in specific activity versus Pt
catalyst (Figure 6D and E); the specific activity of Pt3Co reaches 3.2 mA/cm 2 , 3.0 and 2.3 mA/cm 2 for Pt3Ni and Pt3Fe, The Pt3Co NPs were found to have the highest specific and mass activity among different Pt-alloy NPs, which is consistent to what has been observed on extended surfaces. Although the shape-controlled synthesis of monometallic nanocrystals with high-index facets has been studied extensively, alloy nanocrystals, such as nanooctahedra, truncated nanooctahedra, and nanoicosahedra, bound by high-index facets have not been thoroughly explored due to the difficulties in controlling high energy surfaces in the presence of two metals with different nucleation and growth properties. Initial study on single crystalline Pt3Ni(111) [39] has established an ultimate goal in synthesis which was supposed to be a PtNi octahedral particle with highly efficient (111) facets of Pt skin Among many reports that claimed shape controlled electrocatalytic behavior, Fang et al. described a new wet-chemical approach of synthesizing monodisperse octahedral Pt3Ni NPs and nanocubes terminated with (111) and (100) facets, respectively [47]. The octahedral Pt3Ni NPs were synthesized by the reduction of Ni(acac)2and Pt(acac)2 with W(CO)6; the presence of W(CO)6 was the key to control the morphology of the Pt3Ni NPs shape, since tungsten does not alloy with Pt under the reaction conditions, and therefore, was not detected in the final NP product. The specific activity of Pt3Ni nanoctahedra in weakly-adsorbing electrolyte 0.1 M HClO4 was 5.1 times higher when compared to the Pt3Ni nanocubes and ~6.5 times to the Pt nanocubes, while the mass activity was ~2.8 and ~3.6 times higher than that of Pt3Ni and Pt nanocubes, respectively. Meanwhile, the specific and mass activities of Pt3Ni-octa/C were ~7 and ~4 times, higher than those of the commercial Pt/C catalysts. Therefore, the Pt3Ni nanooctahedra prepared through this new synthesis strategy should be considered as a promising ORR electrocatalyst, with possibility to extended preparation method towards the other shape-controlled systems. An approach to the synthesis of faceted Pt alloy nanocrystals was subsequently developed based on the use of CO gas, which showed a similar ORR activity trend [48]. Different PtM alloy (M = Co, Fe, Ni, Pd) nanocrystals with cubic and octahedral morphologies were obtained by the CO-based method, which was capable to produce Pt bimetallic nanocrystals with a range of
compositions and morphologies. Another relevant example was reported by Xia et al. in which the uniform 9 nm PtNi octahedral NPs with (111) facets were obtained by using a decomposed CO from W(CO)6 as a capping agent in the presence of Ni [49]. The synthesized Pt-Ni octahedrons achieved significantly high specific activity when compared to commercial Pt/C catalyst a as well as high mass activity of 3.3 A/mgPt at 0.9 V. As mentioned above, segregation of site-dependent metal surface can largely affect the catalytic activity and stability. Nevertheless, segregation on well-defined shaped alloy nanocatalysts and their atomic-scale evolution is still largely unexplored. Strasser et al. presented a series of morphologies in shaped particles and correlate these with their surface electrocatalytic ORR activity (Figure 7) [50]. Octahedral Pt1.5Ni, PtNi and PtNi1.5 NPs were prepared using a dimethylformamide-based solvothermal method at 120 °C, which were used to investigate the compositional patterns inside pristine PtxNi1-x nano-octahedra, follow their distinct morphological and compositional evolution trajectories with atomic-scale resolution before and after cycling of electrochemical potential. Electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) line analysis was applied to further investigate metal segregation. Pt1.5Ni showed Pt-rich facets of 2-4 atomic layers in thickness, whereas the PtNi sample shows a mixed facet alloy surface. Higher bulk Ni content in PtNi1.5 resulted in facets with 4-7 atomic layers of segregated Ni. The ORR activities of the Pt1.5Ni, PtNi and PtNi1.5 NPs reached the highest values from their initial performance after 25 potential cycles from 0.06-1.0 V vs. RHE. The PtNi showed the ORR improvement in mass and specific activities, which was 6-10 times in mass activities and a 10-15 times in specific activities relative to commercial Pt nanoparticle electrocatalysts, respectively. Subsequent atomic-scale morphological and structural changes of the catalysts were simultaneously monitored. Dealloyed PtNi octahedra developed very thin Pt shells along (111) facets with beginning concave topology, which enabled both electronic and surface lattice strain to modify the electronic structure that had led towards favorable adsorption and catalytic properties. Generally, the segregation and leaching mechanisms revealed here highlighted the complexity of the shape-selective
nanoalloys and their evolution under reactive conditions. More recent study showed additional shape effects on the Pt icosahedron NPs bounded by the stable (111) facets for the ORR activity [51]. Yang et al, described the synthesis of a set of PtM (M = Au, Ni, Pd) icosahedral nanocrystals based on the gas reducing agent in liquid solution method, which is rarely made in a highly uniform fashion due to the greatly increased strain energy caused by the twin defects. The Pt3Ni NPs had an impressive ORR specific activity of 1.83 mA/cmPt 2 and and mass activity of 0.62 A/mgPt among the PtM alloy icosahedral nanocrystals. Moreover, the specific activity of icosahedral Pt3Ni catalysts was also 50% higher than that of the octahedral with a similar particle size, despite the fact that both shapes were bound by (111) facets (Figure 8). DFT and molecular dynamics simulations indicated that this improvement may arise from electronic effects induced by strain that can vary for different shapes.

sections.heading: 4.2 Core-Shell Systems
sections.text:
Core-shell NPs represent a subclass of multimetallic systems with adjustable properties [52,53]. In order to optimize utilization and mass activity of Pt, an ultimate goal would be to produce a thin shell or skin layers of Pt or Pt alloy over the non-Pt NP core. Because of their structural complexity as compared with simple alloys, core-shell structures still remain unexplored for the issues associated with degradation and corresponding durability. For instance, core-shell NPs, such as Au@Pt, AuCu@Pt, Pd@Pt, Cu@Pt and Ni@Pt, have been successfully fabricated and characterized with significantly enhanced ORR catalysis [54–60]. Galvanic displacement is one of the most successfully applied methods to deposit Pt monolayers on the surface of different metals. As reported by Adzic, Brankovic and co-workers, Cu is commonly used as the sacrificial layer for creating core shell structures, while Pt is subsequently deposited on different metallic cores through the electrochemical replacement reaction [61–63]. This elegant approach was used to synthesize Pt monolayers on Pd or PdAu alloy cores supported on carbon (PtML@Pd/C and PtML@Pd9Au1/C) NPs by UPD and replacement reactions [64]. For the PtML@Pd/C, the mass activity was 3 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C catalysts, and only
decreases 37% after 100,000 cycles compared to almost 70 % loss after 60,000 cycles for the commercial Pt/C catalysts, indicating excellent durability of this electrocatalyst. Further improvement of the PtML@Pd/C monolayer electrocatalyst was achieved by alloying Pd with a small amount of gold to obtain a Pd9Au1 alloy core. Consequently, in these Pd or Pd9Au1 supported Pt monolayer core/shell nanoparticles, the core increases the stability of the shell by shifting positively oxidation potential. This study demonstrated a broad applicability of the Pt monolayer catalysts and the possibility of extending this concept to the catalysts based on other noble metals. Recently, removal of the surface non-Pt metal followed by thermal annealing was introduced to make another type of core-shell NPs. Based on initial study on extended surfaces, we pursued the design and synthesis of the catalyst that contained a distinct nanoscale architecture with a PtNi core of 50 at.% Ni and a multilayered Pt-skin surfaces, which showed superior electrocatalytic performance for the ORR [65]. First, Pt thin films with controlled thickness (1-7 ML) were deposited on PtNi substrate by magnetron sputtering. These films showed a Pt-skeleton type of surfaces, with 3 ML Pt being most active which revealed a good Pt surface coverage and was still thin enough to benefit from the alloy substrate. The rough surface with substantial amount of under-coordinated Pt sites from the as-sputtered thin films was smoothed by annealing, creating a multilayered Pt-skin surface. This was evidenced by the significant enhancement of the ORR activity as well as the difference in ECSA obtained from CO stripping and Hupd. Such findings on the extended surfaces provided guidance for preparation of nanosized catalysts. As a result, the PtNi NPs were synthesized by simultaneous reduction of Pt(acac)2 and Ni(ac)2 in an organic solution, then leached in acid to dissolve exposed Ni atoms, leaving a Pt-skeleton surface structure. Subsequent thermal treatment converted the Pt-skeleton into a multilayered Pt-skin structure by surface relaxation and restructuring of the topmost Pt atoms. The representative high angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images taken along the <110> zone axis of the as-prepared (left), acid treated (middle), and acid treated/annealed (right) PtNi NPs
were shown in Figure 9. The distribution of Pt and Ni in the as-prepared catalyst was highly intermixed and the sketched trend lines were almost identical. Moreover, substantially broader distribution of Pt than Ni, with a difference of ~1 nm for the acid treated and ~0.6 nm for the acid treated/annealed catalyst, was observed. This indicated that multilayered Pt-rich surface structure was formed by acid treatment and preserved after annealing. The acid treated and acid treated/annealed PtNi/C catalysts exhibited enhanced specific activities of the ORR at 0.95 V (0.35 and 0.85 mA/cm 2 ), which are 3 and over 6 times of Pt/C catalysts (0.13 mA/cm 2 ), respectively. After 4,000 potential cycles, the acid treated/annealed PtNi/C catalyst showed superior stability with only 15% loss in specific activity, in contrast to 57% for the acid treated catalyst and 38% for Pt/C. Substantially enhanced catalytic activity and durability of the catalyst with multilayered Pt-skin surfaces indicated great potential for improving the material properties by fine-tuning of the nanoscale architecture. Surface dealloying of the MPt to form Pt@PtM NPs with unique compositional profiles also has been recognized as valuable approach in enhancing both activity and durability of the ORR [66–70]. On the other hand, core-shell structures can also be generated by direct thermal annealing or electrochemically cycling of the as-prepared PtM alloy NPs. Dealloyed PtM@Pt NPs similarly showed improved ORR activity and stability [71,72]. Abruña et al. reported a new class of Pt-Co nanocatalysts composed of ordered Pt3Co intermetallic cores with a 2-3 atomic-layer-thick Pt shell by an annealing process on a disordered Pt3Co alloy [71]. The Pt shell was strained due to the ordered intermetallic core, which has a 0.8% smaller lattice constant than the disordered alloy. The carbon-supported Pt3Co NPs (Pt3Co/C) were synthesized by pre-treatment of the as-prepared Pt3Co/C with an impregnation reduction method at different temperatures under a flowing H2/N2 atmosphere, denoted as Pt3Co/C, Pt3Co/C-400 and Pt3Co/C-700. The intermetallic phase of Pt3Co/C-700 exhibited marked activity improvements over Pt/C and disordered Pt3Co/C-400 alloy NPs. The specific activity of Pt3Co/C-700 was 1.1 mA/cmPt 2 at 0.9 V, the mass activity was higher than that of Pt-Co/C systems from the literature tested under similar conditions at 0.90 V. As a
result of the Pt shell and ordered Pt3Co intermetallic cores, these NPs, characterized by a stable ordered core-shell structure, showed a much higher durability with stability tests, evincing a minimal loss of activity even after 5,000 potential cycles. This study provided a new approach to synthesize ORR catalysts with excellent electrocatalytic activity and durability. Feasibility to generate advanced electrocatalysts based on ultrathin Pt-skin formation, still remains challenging to execute at atomic scale. Another approach to synthesize similar type of structure would be to direct deposition of Pt layers over the core [73– 76]. Xia et al. described a new route to directly deposit conformal and ultrathin Pt overlayers on Pd nanocube with a precise control over the number of Pt atomic layers [77]. Slow injection of a Pt precursor at a sufficiently high temperature was the key in success of this approach, which could evenly spread Pt atoms across the entire surface of a Pd seed to produce Pd@PtnL core-shell nanocubes. The thickness of the Pt shell could be controlled from one to six atomic layers by varying the amount of Pt precursor added into the system. The Pd@PtnL core-shell nanocubes exhibited significant improvement in the ORR activity and durability compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst and Pt nanocubes, which was attributed to the weakening of OH binding through the ligand and strain effects as evidenced by DFT calculations. A volcano-type relationship between the ORR specific activity and the number of Pt atomic layers was also observed, which is in good agreement with the experimental results. In particular, the ORR specific activity was maximized for the catalysts based on Pd@Pt2-3L nanocubes among all of the Pd@PtnL catalysts tested.

sections.heading: 4.3 Nanomaterials with Complex Architectures
sections.text:
With advances in material science and nanotechnology, porous Pt-based nanomaterials with controlled composition, shape, and geometrical configuration have also been applied as advanced ORR catalysts [78–81]. Jaramillo and co-workers synthesized mesoporous double gyroid (DG) Pt with approximately 50-300 nm diameter by electrodeposition of Pt into a mesoporous silica film [82]. The resultant meso-structured Pt exhibited higher specific activity for the ORR than the commercial
Pt/C electrocatalyst, as well as a better durability, which can be attributed to the continuous nature of the Pt structure. The catalytic performance of porous systems was further improved by fabricating Pt-based binary and/or multimetallic catalysts. A variety of Pt-based alloy catalysts with porous structure have been investigated, such as PtFe, PtPd, PtCu, PtCo, PtNi, PtPdCu, PtCuCoNi [83,84]. Another valuable approach to enhance the performance of Pt-based catalysts has been utilization of nanostructures which possess desirable attributes such as high aspect ratios, fewer lattice boundaries, long segments of smooth crystal planes and a low number of surface defect sites [85–88]. Recent experiments indicate that Pt-alloys in the form of nanowires (NWs), are less subjected to dissolution, Ostwald ripening and aggregation than the Pt NPs in acidic condition, while maintaining excellent catalytic properties for the ORR [89–92]. For example, FePt (or CoPt) NWs were synthesized by using a simple decomposition of Fe(CO)5 (or Co2(CO)8) and reduction of Pt(acac)2 in organic solution [93]. The annealed 6.3 nm wide FePt NWs showed high specific activity of 3.9 mA/cm 2 at 0.9 V and 0.46 mA/cm 2 at 0.95 V than the benchmark Pt catalyst. Furthermore, their ORR polarization curve overlaps with the one before the stability test after 4,000 potential cycles. Meanwhile, the activity of the thinner NWs (~2nm in diameter) could be enhanced after removal of Ni or Cu with acid leaching. Additionally, Pd or Au was doped to the thin (~2.5 nm) PtFe NWs or PtFeM/PtFe core/shell NWs (M = Au or Pd) and showed improvement of the ORR activity [94,95]. Another type of particles based on nanocages with subnanometer-thick walls were developed by Xia and co-workers [96,97]. These NPs exhibited distinctive catalytic activities and stability toward the ORR that was attributed to the shortening of Pt-Pt interatomic distances [98]. In this approach, four atomic layers of Pt were coated on the surfaces of Pd nanocubes and octahedras. Then Pt nanocages with walls as thin as three atomic layers (0.7 nm thick) and (100) or (111) terminated surfaces were obtained by selective removal of the Pd templates. The octahedral nanocages showed the highest mass and specific activity, which were five and almost eight times greater than those of commercial Pt/C catalysts. The Pt octahedral nanocages also showed the best performance with only 36% loss of mass activity after 10,000 cycling stability
test, which was still 3.4-fold enhancement relative to the Pt/C. It is well-known that catalytic properties of materials strongly depend on their microscopic structure, with the atomic-level chemistry and structure directly influencing the activity and durability of the catalyst. The introduction of a porous or hollow structure to the interior nanocrystals can increase the surface area-to-volume ratio and diminish the number of buried non-functional precious metal atoms [97– 101]. In our recent study, we synthesized a highly active and durable class of electrocatalysts by transforming solid PtNi3 polyhedral nanoparticles into an open-cell three-dimensional (3D) frame [102]. The ~20 nm rhombic dodecahedron PtNi3 NPs with single crystalline fcc atomic structure were firstly synthesized in organic solution. After Ni was leached out in a chemical solution, 3D Pt3Ni nanoframes were formed and shaped like open truss structures (Figure 10). The Pt3Ni nanoframe catalysts exhibited greatly enhanced mass and specific activity at 0.95 V compared to that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst. After the ionic liquid was encapsulated within open nanoframe structure, the Pt3Ni nanoframes exhibited 36 and 22 fold enhancements in mass and specific activity. More importantly, the stability of Pt3Ni nanoframe was also impressive. After 10,000 cycling durability test, they still maintained their morphology confirmed by STEM, while activity loss was negligible. The open structure of the Pt3Ni nanoframes provides a promising pathway to combine material architecture and nanoscale design. Modifying Pt NPs with other metals may prevent the oxidation of Pt and improve the stability of the Pt NPs, which is beneficial to the ORR performance. For example, amorphous Au clusters deposited on Pt/C NPs showed excellent durability after potential cycling test. Adzic and co-workers, introduced tiny Au nanoclusters on the surface of Pt/C catalyst and found that the clusters induced a change in the electronic behavior of of Pt, which prevented platinum atoms from dissolving [103]. There were insignificant changes in the activity and surface area of Au-modified Pt over the course of cycling, which were attributed to an increased nobility of the surface Pt atoms and increased oxidation potential. However, Au on the surface may act to block active Pt sites, negatively impacting the activity at high current densities. In our recent
work, complex hierarchical NPs with the Au as the interlayer between a Ni core and a PtNi alloy shell have been developed (Figure 11) [104]. The multimetallic core/interlayer/shell nanostructures have the optimal balance of activity and durability due to the synergy between the stabilizing effect of subsurface Au and modified electronic structure of surface Pt through interaction with subsurface Ni atoms. The specific and mass activity enhancement of Ni@Au@PtNi/C was improved over 8 times versus the Pt/C and outperforms multilayered Pt-skin PtNi/C due to the replacement of expensive Pt and/or Au with Ni in the core. Meanwhile, the Ni@Au@PtNi/C electrocatalysts possess superior durability toward the ORR without noticeable loss in either ECSA or specific activity after 10,000 potential cycles between 0.6 and 1.1 V. This approach may be readily applied as a general strategy toward novel design of multimetallic core/interlayer/shell systems. As mentioned previously, bimetallic PtNi nanostructures have been widely reported as catalysts with impressive catalytic activity, but further improvement in high catalytic activity and durability that would match values obtained on bulk single crystals are expected. More recently, Huang et al. reported novel system by doping the Pt3Ni octahedrons with another more oxophilic transition metals, denoted as M-Pt3Ni/C [105]. The Pt3Ni octahedral NPs were firstly prepared in the N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution, then dopant precursors, such as Mo(CO)6, together with Pt(acac)2 and Ni(acac)2 were added, an reacted at 170 °C for 48 hours. Among a series of transition metals, the Mo-Pt3Ni/C exhibited the best ORR activity, with a specific activity of 10.3 mA/cm 2 and mass activity of 6.98 A/mgPt, which are 81 and 73 fold enhancements compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst (0.127 mA/cm 2 and 0.096 A/mgPt). After 8,000 cycles, the Mo-Pt3Ni/C only showed 6.2 and 5.5% loss from the initial specific activity and mass activity, respectively. To date, the possibility of achieving the unique structural and compositional profile of the Pt3Ni(111) alloy still remains as a challenge, which could bring unprecedented benefits to the ORR catalysis [106,107]. A notable attempt in getting closer to the activity values of single crystalline Pt-alloy surfaces was our recent work on thin film catalysts [107]. We developed a new class of catalytically active materials based on
mesostructured thin films (Meso-TF) with adjustable composition and surface morphology. Surface properties of Meso-TF have been tailored to emulate the distinctive behavior of the Pt3Ni(111)-skin (Figure 12). In the process of development, firstly, the Pt thin films were deposited onto a clean GC substrate, which was followed by thermal annealing in a reductive atmosphere. The morphology of the annealed thin film has been transformed into a smooth two-dimensional surface with large 20 x 100 nm hexagonal (111) facets, which were also confirmed by the scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM) results and CV. In the following steps a bimetallic PtNi thin film with the same thickness was prepared to mimic the composition profile of the Pt3Ni(111) system. In a subsequent set of experiments we applied the same approach towards the nanostructured thin films (NSTF) catalysts, consecutive layers of Pt and the metal of choice deposited onto the oriented organic pigment (perylene red) whiskers by planar magnetron sputter deposition in vacuum. The highly corrugated surface of as-sputtered NSTFs could be gradually smoothed by slow heating up to 400 °C. The decreased Hupd with a plateau as well as the substantially elevated ORR specific activity at 0.95 V was attributed to the formation of Pt3Ni(111) skin on the surface of Meso-TF catalyst. Moreover, mesostructure preserved relatively high ECSA, while the ORR activity of the Meso-TF exceeded the highest value reported for bulk polycrystalline Pt bimetallic alloys being 20 fold more active than commercial Pt/C catalysts. In addition, mesostructured surfaces were found to be resistant towards surface area loss due to the lower number of under-coordinated surface atoms and lack of carbon corrosion. The approach as developed can be applied to generate a wide range of (electro) catalysts with tailored structure/composition, ultralow precious metal content and superior functional properties such as activity and durability.

sections.heading: 5 Pt-free catalysts
sections.text:
Besides the efforts that have been focused on lowering platinum loading, researchers also investigated possibility to substitute Pt with other metals. As of now, a number of non-Pt metal based ORR catalysts have been reported [108–110]. In general, the reaction mechanism for these systems was not thoroughly studied, compared to Pt. For
the pure metals, both theoretical calculation and experimental results have shown that Pd, a congener of Pt, may be a candidate for the ORR catalyst with enhanced methanol tolerance [111]. Nørskov and coworkers [112] indicated that with the exception of Pt, Pd has the smallest overpotentials for the ORR in terms of density functional theory (DFT) calculated oxygen and hydroxide binding energies. This was in line with a few experimental results obtained from H3PO4 [113], HClO4 [114] and NaOH [115]. Kondo and colleagues [116] compared the ORR activity of different Pd crystal orientations in 0.1 M HClO4 with that of Pt surfaces. Similar to Pt, the ORR activity of Pd single crystals is also dependant on the arrangement of surface atoms. However, the observed activity order is opposite to that of Pt in perchloric acid at 0.90 V vs. RHE. The most active Pd(100) (1.67 mA/cm 2 ) was nearly 3 times of Pt(110) (0.60 mA/cm 2 ), followed by the inactive Pd(111) (0.12 mA/cm 2 ) and Pd(110) (0.04 mA/cm 2 ). They further investigated the ORR activity on higher index planes n(100)-(111) and n(100)-(110). The results showed almost the same linear enhancement of the ORR activity for both series as the terrace atomic row n increases, indiscriminating the different step structures. Such findings about facet-dependency on single crystals were also confirmed on nanoparticles from aqueous synthesis [117]. In this study, Pd nanocubes (~6 nm) were made from reduction of Na2PdCl4 by L-ascorbic acid in the presence of chloride and bromide anions (Figure 13A, B); while Pd octahedral NPs of similar size (5-6 nm) were obtained by mixing Na2PdCl4 with citric acid, ethanol and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (Figure 13C, D). RDE results showed that the ORR activity of the cubes (0.31 mA/cm 2 ) is nearly 10 times higher than that of the octahedra (0.033 mA/cm 2 ) and comparable with that of annealed commercial Pt/C (0.32 mA/cm 2 ) (Figure 13E). The origin of increased ORR activity on Pd(100) surface is yet to be understood. In spite of a big leap from Pd(111) enclosed octahedra, the ORR activity of (100) enclosed cubic Pd NPs is still poor compared to that of the Pt based alloy catalysts, as pure Pd metal binds oxygen a bit too strongly. Like in case of Pt, Pd based alloys with controlled surface structure have been studied to improve the ORR activity [118,119]. For instance, Savadogo et al. sputtered PdM (M = Co, Cr) thin films [120]. They found
higher ORR activity for PdCo (28% Co in molar ratio) compared with bulk Pt. In another study, Shao et al. [114] deposited monolayer Pd skin on top of different noble metal (111) surfaces by galvanic displacement of underpotetially deposited Cu. The highest activity was obtained from Pd/Pt(111), which was still a bit lower than Pt(111). Annealed Pd2Co NPs with large size (~17 nm) and size distribution supported on carbon showed similar activity to that of commercial Pt/C. They achieved even higher activity on Pd3Fe/C (~ 9.7 nm), [121,122] in which the kinetic current was correlated with the Pd-Pd bond distance as a function of Fe content in the alloy. Strain caused by change in bond distance could modify the electronic structure and hence could affect adsorption and catalytic properties. Tang and Henkelman [123] specifically discussed charge redistribution within the core/shell NPs. As a result, adsorption of oxygenated species could be weakened in the PdM system, leading to a higher ORR activity. Recently, other groups have also reported similar findings on PdFe [124–128], PdCo [129–132], PdNi [133–135], PdTi [136,137], PdCu [138–141]. In addition, some tri-metallic Pd based alloy systems with tailored lattice strain such as PdCoMo [142] and PdCoFe [143] have also been prepared and the ORR activity was found to be higher than pure Pd. In addition, Ir was doped into the PdFe [144] and PdCu [145] with further enhanced activity. More importantly, Pd metal is sensitive to corrosion in strong acids under the ORR condition as significant Pd dissolution happens above 0.8 V when the pH equals 1 [146]. Although the PdCo and PdCr sputtered thin films appeared to be stable during experiment [120], not many of the above-mentioned alloy systems have undergone long term stability test in acid electrolyte [128,134,142,141]. In the past decade, the stabilization effect of Au in Pt-based ORR catalysts has been well-documented [147– 149]. In a similar way, Au has been added to the PdM alloy systems with the aim of boosting the durability performance of Pd based catalysts. Based on their high throughput screening results from scanning electrochemical microscopy [118], Bard’s group prepared PdCoAu/C catalysts of varied composition using a reverse microemulsion method and subsequently annealed them at 500-900 °C [136]. They found the highest activity on Pd70Co20Au10 after annealing at 750 °C, showing a good
extent of alloying without significant sintering by XRD. The activity was better than Pd80Co20 and even slightly higher than commercial Pt catalyst. Stability test was carried out by polarizing the cell at 200 mA/cm 2 for 12 h. After that, some activity drop was observed on the polarization curve especially at high current density region, which was attributed to the Co leaching out. However, in the follow-up work, they found even better activity and stability performance by replacing Au with Mo [142]. In this case, lower annealing temperature (500 °C) was more beneficial to mitigate the possible sintering while still promoting crystallinity. Nevertheless, the performance enhancement cannot be fully explained by the particle size effect, because the Pd70Co20Au10 (12-15 nm) is smaller than Pd70Co20Mo10 (~24 nm, 500 °C annealed). Wei and coworkers [150] synthesized PdCoAu/C via a deposition-precipitation approach and annealed it in CO/Ar (10% CO, vol) at 470-570 K. They used a temperature programmed reduction (TPR) technique to characterize the surface composition of the alloy upon annealing. The optimal heating temperature was determined to be 520 K (CO520), which induced formation of the PdCo and PdAu core/PdAu-enriched shell structure. Although 6 times higher mass activity was observed in this CO520 catalyst compared to Pd/C, it still fell below the activity of the commercial Pt/C. In another report, Koenigsmann et al. [151] synthesized Pd9Au nanowires with higher specific activity than Pt/C. More recently, Adzic and coworkers [152] reported a structurally ordered Pd40Co50Au10/C catalyst. First, disordered PdCoAu/C catalyst with a Co-core/PdAu shell structure was prepared from aqueous synthesis followed by annealing at 500 °C in H2. When annealed at 800 °C, ordered PdCo alloy structure was obtained in the presence of Au, which acted as a matrix keeping NPs from agglomeration. The ORR polarization curves in acid (Figure 14A) indicated similar onset and half wave potentials for the intermetallic PdCoAu/C compared with those of commercial Pt/C, while the disordered core/shell PdCoAu/C was less active. In alkaline environment (Figure 14B), both ordered and disordered PdCoAu/C showed similar ORR activity to the Pt/C. Stability test was carried out by cycling the catalysts in 0.1 M KOH between 0.6 V and 1.0 V for 10,000 cycles. Figure 14C and Figure 14D show almost no perceivable drop in the ORR activity or ECSA;
while commercial Pt/C suffered significant degradation. Based on post stability test analysis by HRTEM and EELS, Figure 14E shows elemental distribution in a catalyst NP with a Pd-rich surface and most of Co preserved underneath. The authors ascribed the enhanced stability performance to the gold clusters on the surface (not shown in Figure 14E) together with the structural ordering of PdCo. In another study, Sun et al. [153] reported on the enhanced ORR performance in 0.1 M KOH for the M/PdCu (M = Ag or Au) core/shell NPs with controlled shell thickness and composition compared with commercial Pt/C (0.06 A/mgPt at -0.1 V vs. Ag/AgCl). Among them, Ag/Pd63Cu37 (0.18 A/mgPd) and Au/Pd60Cu40 (0.20 A/mgAu+Pd) NPs with 0.75 and 1.1 nm shells were more efficient. The Ag/Pd63Cu37 also showed lower decay of the ORR current compared with that of commercial Pt/C during 48,000 s chronoamperometry. That was achieved by the fine tuning of the surface strain along with composition of the core/shell NPs. Liu et al. [154] synthesized five-fold twined Pd2NiAg nanocrystals with Ni-rich surface which showed high stability performance in 0.1 M KOH. Despite all progress made on Pd based catalysts for the ORR, it should be noted that none of them is anywhere near to the state-of-art Pt alloy catalysts with Pt3Ni(111)-like Pt-skin surface in terms of ORR activity in acid. Besides that, the instability of Pd in acid under the ORR condition also hinders its application in PEMFC. Moreover, Pd itself is still a precious metal, and hence, significant cost is still involved in producing this type of catalyst. For these reasons, discovery of new ORR catalysts made from earth-abundant non-precious metal compounds/composites is highly desirable to further meet cost demands for broad application of fuel cells technology. As of now, several systems based on non-precious metals have been reported to show some ORR activities, including transition metal oxides, chalcogenides, carbides, nitrides and phosphides [155–167]. The most promising candidate was found to have M-N-C (M = Co and/or Fe) structures after heat treatment [168,169]. In spite of the ongoing debate regarding the nature of the active sites, the goal in this M-N-C catalyst development is to enhance the active site turnover frequency, the active site density and structural durability under relevant ORR conditions. Since cobalt phthalocyanine was tested as fuel cell cathode catalyst more than 5 decades ago [170], significant progress has been
made in probing the catalytic mechanisms and improving the overall performance. Bashyam and Zelenay [171] synthesized a cobalt-polypyrrole-carbon (Co-PPY-C) composite catalyst without pyrolysis. The catalyst showed ~0.2 A/cm 2 at 0.5 V and its maximum power density reached 0.15 W/cm 2 in H2-O2 atmosphere. In addition, there was no current drop after the cell was operating at 0.4 V or 0.5 V for more than 100 h. The same group [172] later used polyaniline (PANI) as precursor to build PANI-FeCo-C type of catalysts upon heat treatments. They reported maximum power density of 0.55 W/cm 2 and excellent stability in both MEA holding and RDE cycling test, which may be attributed to the disordered carbon structure enhancing active-site formation and corrosion resistivity. Lefèvre and et al. [173] prepared microporous catalyst in which contains iron coordinated by pyridinic nitrogen functionalities in the interstices of graphitic sheets. The active site density was increased during synthesis by introducing the pore filler and planetary ball-milling in combination with pyrolysis in Ar and then in NH3. At high loading (5.3 mg/cm 2 ) of this Fe-N-C catalyst, ORR current density at 0.9 V was almost equal to that of the Pt/C catalyst with 0.4 mgPt/cm 2 loading. However, the performance dropped substantially at high current density region below 0.7 V, which was associated with the mass transport on the catalyst. More than half the H2-O2 activity lost (from 0.75 A/cm 2 to 0.33 A/cm 2 at 0.5 V) after durability test at 0.5 V for 100 h. The activity performance was further enhanced in catalyst derived from iron-acetate/phenanthroline/Zn(II)-zeolitic-imidazolate-framework [174], with a peak power density of 0.91 W/cm 2 . The high temperature of pyrolysis in Ar and subsequent pyrolysis in NH3 led to the high surface area and activity (1,120 A/g at 0.8 V) of the product, with larger surface area observed from high temperature treatment, which also induced the Fe-N-C structure formation evidenced by nitrogen coordination number change. Nevertheless, durability performance for the most active batch of catalyst remained a challenge as significant activity drop observed upon 100-h potential holding at 0.5 V. Very recently, with the help of in situ X-ray adsorption technique, Mukerjee et al. [175] confirmed the Fe-N site helped with oxygen adsorption and reduction to peroxide intermediate in both acid and alkaline. Zitolo et al. [176] identified FeN4C12 moieties as the catalytic sites in this system. The elevated ORR activity of FeN4C12
moieties was attributed to the creation of highly basic N-groups by the heat treatment in NH3. On the other hand, further advancements in electrocatalytic activity and durability performance have been reported on various M-N-C type catalysts [177–183], highlighting the significance of having high BET surface area for active site density and micro/meso-porous structure for mass transport. With such immense progress made in the past decade on the non-precious metal catalyst, continuous improvement is still needed to bridge the gap with Pt-based alloy catalysts for higher power density and durability, which will also benefit from a deeper understanding of the active sites.

sections.heading: 6 Summary
sections.text: Improevements of the ORR kinetics are still necessary in order to avoid limitations in commercialization of fuel cell technology.. Currently, Pt-based catalysts represent the most practical systems for the ORR due to high activity and acceptable durability. In order to facilitate the maximum catalytic activity of ORR, the adsorption energies of reactive intermediates and surface coverage by spectator oxygenated species and specifically adsorbed anions on the catalyst surface should be balanced. In the past decades, great progress in understanding the fundamentals of the ORR has been made in respect of the design and optimization. Highly active Pt-based systems have been prepared by modulating the size, compositional profile and morphology, which showed potent approach to boost their catalytic properties. This review listed a number of preparation approaches and selected advanced metal and alloy nanostructures with significantly improved ORR performance. These new approaches may not only have a large impact on the ORR catalysis but also are beneficial in designing functional materials that could be applied beyond fuel cells.

Program. The authors thank to Chao Wang, Joshua Snyder, Dennis van der Vliet, Dusan Tripkovic, Yijin Kang, Deborah Myers, Peidong Yang and Karren More for many years of collaboration that has led to a number of publications in the field of fuel cell electrocatalysis.

metadata.abstractText: In the past decade, polymer electrolyte membrane fuels (PEMFCs) have been evaluated for both automotive and stationary applications. One of the main obstacles for large scale commercialization of this technology is related to the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction that takes place on the cathode side of fuel cell. Consequently, ongoing research efforts are focused on the design of cathode materials that could improve the kinetics and durability. Majority of these efforts rely on novel synthetic approaches that provide control over the structure, size, shape and composition of catalytically active materials. This article highlights the most recent advances that have been made to tailor critical parameters of the nanoscale materials in order to achieve more efficient performance of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR).
metadata.creator: Elsevier
